Ms Thornberry was a good sport, laughed and took it in good humour.

title: eu citizens brexit apply explained
story: NewsEU citizens' rights after Brexit explained - can I stay in UK and how do I apply?Ministers have revealed the EU Settlement Scheme 3.8million EU citizens will use to stay in the UK. Here's what we know and your key questions answered&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan BloomPolitical reporter16:37, 21 JUN 2018Updated16:45, 21 JUN 2018News3.8million EU citizens will have to use the scheme if they want to stay (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUK officials have unveiled the process EU citizens must go through to remain in Britain after Brexit . Ministers today revealed details of the EU Settlement Scheme, which the UK's 3.8million EU citizens will have to use if they want to stay. Former Home Secretary Amber Rudd infamously claimed it would be “as easy as setting up an online account at LK Bennett” - a posh shoe shop. And Home Secretary Sajid Javid said it will be simple and straightforward adding: We will be looking to grant, not for reasons to refuse. So what do we know about the rights available to EU citizens in the UK - and how will they change? Here’s everything we know, including the costs, deadlines, and how to apply.  Britain and Brussels have agreed EU nationals can continue arriving, working and settling in the UK until 31 December 2020. So anyone who arrives before that date will have the right to apply to stay in the UK permanently. This will also apply the other way round, for Brits in the other 27 EU nations. It's not yet known what rights people will get if they arrive after that deadline. It's been suggested EU citizens will get preferential immigration rights compared to people from the rest of the world, but that's not confirmed.  EU citizens who have been in the UK for five years or more by the 31 December 2020 will be able to apply for settled status. This means they are free to continue living and working in the UK. People who have not lived in the UK for five years must apply for pre-settled status.  This gives them the right to stay until they reach the five year mark. At that point, they must apply again for the right to stay. When should I start applying?  The scheme will launch in the second half of 2018. Chiefs hope to begin testing an online platform with a small number of real cases from the end of the summer. There will then be a phased roll-out later this year. The Home Office says the scheme will be open fully by 30 March 2019 - the day after Britain officially leaves the EU. When is the deadline to apply? People who arrive by December 31, 2020 can apply for the scheme. The scheme will close to applications on 30 June 2021. How much will it cost?  EU citizens who live in the UK will pay a one-off charge of &pound65. This will be halved to &pound32.50 for children under 16. Children in care will have their applications handled for free. Those who already have permanent residence or indefinite leave to remain documents will also be processed for free. Can I apply online or on my phone?    Yes. The Home Office is designing an online application which it says will be simple and user-friendly.  Applicants will be asked to provide their biographical information, declare whether they have any criminal records, and upload a facial photograph. But there's a problem - at the moment, it won't work fully on iPhones. That's because Apple devices cannot read the chips on passports. Home Secretary Sajid Javid admitted: There is an issue at the moment. It's something we are discussing with Apple. Will I have to post off my passport?  Maybe - if you can't use the app. And this could include millions of people with iPhones (see above). The Home Office admits: Those who do not wish to or cannot use the app, or whose identity document is not compatible with it, will need to send us the document by post. Officials are trying to iron out the app problems, and are exploring options to let people attend somewhere to have their documents verified in person. But it's a work in progress. What questions will I be asked? All applicants will have to prove three things. First, they will be asked to prove their identity with a passport or ID card. In many cases this can be scanned and uploaded, but not all (see above). They will also be asked to declare any criminal convictions. And they will be asked to upload a photo of their face. The Home Office will then check employment and benefits data to confirm proof of residence. All those over 10 years old will be checked against crime registers and watch lists. In cases flagged up for concern, overseas criminal records can be checked - but this will not be automatic. Is settled status the same as citizenship?    No - it gives fewer rights, and doesn't offer a UK passport, but it also easier to apply for. EU citizens with settled status will lose that status - and their right to stay in Britain - if they leave the UK for more than five years. However, they will not need to prove their knowledge of language and life in the UK to get settled status. EU citizens who gain settled status in the UK can then apply for full citizenship a year later. What about pre-settled status? This does not grant a permanent right to stay, and EU citizens must keep up continuous residence in the UK to maintain it.  If EU citizens come from 2021 to join someone with settled status, they must keep up their relationship - i.e. a marriage - for five years to be able to qualify for themselves. Can I still go on holiday?  Yes. You have to keep 'continuous residence' for the first five years - but this generally means not leaving the country for more than six months a year. What about family members who live abroad?  Close family members who live abroad will be able to join an EU citizen in the UK after December 2020. Those family members can then apply for the scheme themselves. 'Close family' is defined as a husband or wife, civil partner, dependent child/grandchild, dependent parent/grandparent, or a partner who has lived with their partner for at least two years. Future children are protected, but brothers and sisters are not. Also, husbands/wives need to have either been married or in a 'durable' relationship already by the time of the 31 December 2020 cutoff date. For more details see the full document here. Can I still access the NHS? The Home Office says those who gain the status will have 'the same access as they currently do to healthcare, pensions and other benefits in the UK. This is pretty broad, but not quite the same as the rights UK citizens enjoy. Will I be rejected if I have a minor criminal offence?  No. Or at least, you shouldn't be. The Home Office document said this is a sensible approach, adding: We are not concerned here with minor offences, such as a parking fine. Applications will only be considered for refusal where someone has been convicted of a serious offence. How quickly will I be processed? Officials hope to provide applicants with a response within two weeks.  Will I have an 'ID card'? No. Evidence of settled status will be given to EU citizens in digital form - no physical document will be issued. What if I'm rejected?  Where a valid application is refused, there will be the right to request an administrative review. Someone who has been refused status under the scheme can make a new application at any point before the end of June 2021.  In addition, the government is planning to introduce a law giving a statutory right of appeal for applications made from March 30 next year. Applicants who are refused will be able to re-apply at any point, and however many times they want, up to the end of June 2021. What if I'm from Ireland? Irish citizens enjoy a right of residence in the UK that's separate to the EU. So they will not have to apply for settled status, although they can if they want. What if I'm from Norway, Liechtenstein, Iceland or Switzerland? These countries are not in the EU, but have close ties to Brussels. The UK wants a similar deal for citizens of these nations.  Talks are progressing well and the Home Office hopes to use the above system for these countries too. Is everyone happy about this?    No. Senior MPs have raised concerns hundreds of thousands of EU citizens could fall through the cracks of the new immigration scheme. Home Office ministers were warned that up to 200,000 EU nationals could be left without status if just 5% failed to register before the June 2021 cut-off. SNP home affairs spokeswoman Jo Cherry, speaking in the Commons, said: There are potentially significant numbers of people who could fall through the cracks here. Labour former minister Yvette Cooper, who chairs the Commons Home Affairs Committee, later raised the issue of children and asked what would happen in the event that a child was not registered. She said: Can she say whether this means that after that date they will not be lawfully resident here?  The Home Office - which has presided over bungles including the Windrush scandal - immediately faced questions about whether it will process people efficiently and in time. Some 1,500 Home Office staff will work on the project when it rolls out from Autumn this year - double the current number. Mr Javid admitted: I don't under-estimate the scale of the challenge, I do recognise that. Nothing like this has been done by the Home Office before. But Ms Nokes insisted: We are not anticipating failure. What about British citizens who live in the EU now?  More than 1million British citizens live in the other 27 EU countries. They will have the same rights to stay there as EU citizens have to stay in the UK. But it's not clear if they'll lose the right to move around and settle in any of the other 26 EU countries. Perhaps for this reason, applications for foreign citizenship - especially in Germany - have soared since the Brexit vote. And it's worth noting that among the British citizens that have applied for French residency since the Brexit vote is....Lord Lawson, the former chairman of the Vote Leave campaign.

title: grenfell tower dad two who
story: NewsGrenfell Tower dad-of-two who lived in flat where fire started 'wished he burned with the others'Ethiopian-born Behailu Kebede, 45, said he lost everything in the fire on June 14 last year and has been the victim of false rumours&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJack Hardy15:20, 21 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe father-of-two who lived in the flat where the Grenfell Tower fire started described wishing he had burned in the tower with the others. CCTV images released today show Behailu Kebede, 45, fleeing the tower shortly before 1am on June 14 last year as the fire began to spread. Speaking today, Mr Kebede set out his desperation since losing everything on June 14 last year - compounded by a fear for his life - in a statement to the public inquiry. The Ethiopian-born Uber driver said media coverage painted a completely distorted picture that portrayed him like a criminal who was to blame for the fire. His upsetting written account ended: Sometimes I wish I had burned in the tower with the others. I have been burning inside ever since.  Mr Kebede was woken by the sound of his smoke alarm shortly before 1am on June 14, and found white smoke billowing from behind his fridge-freezer. He alerted his two female housemates, Elsa Afeworki and Almaz Kinfu, before knocking on every door of the neighbouring flats on the block's fourth floor and then rushing outside. Suggestions that he caused the fire by tampering with his fridge-freezer or that he had packed a bag before escaping led to safety concerns from the police. He said in a statement to the inquiry, published on Thursday: I met a number of officers there. They offered to take me to an unknown address outside London for my own protection. They wanted to put me into witness protection because they were concerned about reports in the press that showed me in a negative light, reports suggesting that I was to blame for the fire.  It was even suggested to me that I might need to change my name and not have any contact with my family. I told the police that I did not want to take part in any form of witness protection. Finally, they agreed to let me stay in a different part of London. As a result of the media intrusion, my partner and children were forced to move out of their home. The four of us have been living together in various hotels ever since. Security footage stills shown at the inquiry into the disaster on Thursday pictured Ms Afeworki walking down the stairs into the main lobby at approximately 12.56am, two minutes after the first 999 call. She is followed at around 12.58am by Mr Kebede, who is seen wearing just a T-shirt and a pair of trousers, but no shoes. Within two minutes, the first firefighter is seen entering the building. Mr Kebede had been saving to buy his fourth-floor flat in Grenfell Tower under Right to Buy and hoped to move his partner and two children in with him.  Instead, he left Flat 16 for the final time with only his phone, trousers and T-shirt - not even managing to put on a pair of shoes. His statement continued: Since the Grenfell Tower fire, my life has been a complete mess. For much of the time, I just wanted to be left alone. I had gone through a terrible ordeal that was affecting me mentally and physically. I wanted to meet the families of the bereaved but I did not have the courage to do so. I wanted to pay my respects to the deceased but felt unable to go out on my own. I believed that there were people out there who wanted to hurt my family and me. This was a very difficult time for me. I did not want to live under witness protection but I still took the threat posed to me seriously.  I genuinely feared for my life based on the information that the police gave me at that time. I knew so many of those who died in the fire at Grenfell Tower. I relive the horrific memories of that night all the time. I have not been able to sleep properly, thinking about those who died and seeing their faces when I close my eyes. Just talking about it is painful. I wish I could have banged on more doors and woken up more people. I am haunted by my failure to pick up my flat keys when I left and my inability as a result to get back into the building and warn more people. I feel broken inside. I am not the same man I used to be. I am still in fear, looking over my shoulder all the time. I do not feel comfortable in the presence of groups of four or more. I feel scared, as if I want to cry all the time. Sometimes I cannot even express myself and struggle to speak. Mr Kebede has not given evidence in person at the probe, saying through his lawyer that he was terrified.

title: groom says viral facebook post
story: NewsGroom says viral Facebook post accusing him of cheating on Ibiza holiday has 'ruined his life'Jack Troutt, 23, was enjoying a lad's holiday on the party island and had been sharing stories with pals about previous relationships while sat around the pool&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJessica Cripps14:22, 21 JUN 2018NewsJack Troutt, 23, was enjoying a lad's holiday on the party island when a fellow holidaymaker overheard a conversation between him and pals (Image: Kennedy News and Media / Pic fro)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man claims a stranger's viral Facebook that incorrectly accused him of cheating on his fiancee while on holiday in Ibiza has 'ruined his life.' 'Devastated' Jack Troutt, 23, says his relationship with his beautiful bride-to-be is now at risk and he does not know if she will still want to be with him when he returns home this weekend. He said fellow holidaymaker Steph Kendall, who was was allegedly on a nearby sun lounger, misheard a conversation between his pals during the lads holiday about previous relationships while sat around the pool. Legal firm worker Jack believes Steph misheard what he was saying and thought he was talking about last night - immediately putting a post up instructing his fiancee to 'bin him'. The erroneous post read: If this is your boyfriend Jack staying at the Azuline Bergantin hotel Ibiza him and his friends have been proudly discussing that he cheated on you last night Hun #binhim. The post quickly went viral and received more than 10,000 likes and more than 15,000 shares, with people eventually locating Jack online.  Meanwhile, Love Island's Kady McDermott tweeted the image of Jack with the false accusation to her 357,000 followers, where it quickly started the hashtag #binhim on Twitter too. When he saw the post, Jack was flummoxed by the accusation and rushed to explain to his partner that it was untrue, who was waiting for him back in the UK.  Even when he confronted Steph in the hotel to explain she had misheard him, he claims she walked away from him - and the post remained being shared on Facebook .  Steph, from the North East, claims she removed the post on Tuesday afternoon - around 24 hours after it had been shared. Despite having named and shamed Jack herself, she demanded not be named in the article 'without her permission'. Now Jack is bravely speaking out and calling for tougher regulations on social media users accusing people of things that 'ruin their lives with no concrete evidence'. Jack, from Essex, said: It's devastating because I haven't done anything wrong. I haven't had any sexual relations with a woman on this holiday. I haven't kissed another woman or even kissed another woman on the cheek on this holiday. It's literally bizarre.  In the post she claims I said I slept with someone the previous night. I have two mates of mine who were witnesses there and those sentences never came out of my mouth. She's posted a picture of me online, written a status, done a hashtag saying 'bin him', and now it's gone absolutely viral. [The post is] more or less going to cripple my relationship. It's more or less crippled right now to be honest. My partner is talking about how she's not willing to even get married. It's really upsetting. She's more or less almost cost me my future marriage. It's got to that point now. I can understand it from [my partner's] point of view because if it happened to me, if there was a photo going about saying that she'd said she'd slept with a bloke the previous night, I'd be exactly the same. I'd be really embarrassed and I'd be considering breaking up the relationship as well, like anyone would. At the moment I'm clutching onto straws to try and keep everything together, but it's really difficult. She may not want to be with me by the time I get back.  Jack proposed to his girlfriend in January 2017 and has been in a relationship with her for two years. The distraught holidaymaker was inundated with messages from people who realised the picture was him - and he even worries that his boss at work now knows. Jack said: I am upset. I'm really upset about the whole situation. I am distraught. I am depressed. I am devastated, shocked. I'm in a lot of pain really, emotionally. The story is not true. I don't even know her, she was just sitting on a sunbed next to me while I was talking to a couple of mates about previous relationships and stuff like that. Somehow she claims to have heard me specifically say that I slept with a girl last night. When I confronted her face to face she couldn't tell me what I said. For me, that just makes me wonder how she's come to this point that she's able to say I said these words. I haven't done anything wrong to her, I haven't abused her in any way, I haven't said any names to her in any way.

title: i know didnt roll onto
story: News'I know I didn't roll onto her': Heartbreak of 'intoxicated' mum whose baby girl died in bed beside herAn inquest today heard doctors could not rule out the possibility that Clare Clifford's seven-month-old baby daughter Charlotte died after she rolled over onto her in bed&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySophie EvansBen McVay15:23, 21 JUN 2018Updated16:04, 21 JUN 2018NewsClare Clifford is pictured with her baby girl Charlotte, who died last year (Image: Facebook)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn 'intoxicated' mum whose baby girl died in bed beside her has revealed her heartbreak, saying she knows she didn’t roll onto her. Clare Clifford awoke to find little Charlotte not breathing in the early hours of the morning, with the child pronounced dead soon after.  An inquest today heard doctors could not rule out the possibility that Clare's seven-month-old died in bed after she rolled over onto her.  Evidence from a pathologist found the infant was placed in an unsafe sleeping situation with an intoxicated mother on the night she died. But revealing her devastation earlier this year, light sleeper Clare insisted she just wouldn't have rolled onto her daughter She said: I’m always going to be wondering if I didn’t have her in bed that night - I’ll wonder that for the rest of my life.”  She added: “In my heart of hearts I know I didn’t roll onto Charlotte. I just wouldn’t. I’m such a light sleeper and she was a very vocal baby.” The inquest into Charlotte's death heard how Clare had got into bed with the infant at midnight after drinking with her husband James. The couple had been drinking in their home, the hearing was told, with the mum saying she was in control of herself at all times. She awoke in bed with her baby at 4am on June 18 last year. Charlotte was rushed to Leeds General Infirmary, West Yorkshire, after she was found not breathing, but doctors were unable to save her. She was pronounced dead 45 minutes later. According to evidence from pathologist Michael Parsons read out to the court, there was no specific post-mortem finding confirming death as a result of overlaying. However, the doctor also stated in a report that death caused by overlaying remained a possibility that could not be excluded.  In written evidence read out by coroner Jonathan Leach to Wakefield Coroner's Court, Clare told how she described herself as merry on June 17, 2017. The evidence read On a scale of one-ten I would describe myself as a five. I am used to drinking alcohol and am used to drinking moderately - I was in control of myself at all times. Clare also wrote how she had been advised of the risk of co-sleeping, but she had never been told not to do it. And the digital marketing manager said she had never been told there could be a criminal offence with consuming alcohol. The court heard how she had slept with Charlotte in the bed with her back to the wall while arm-in-arm to prevent the baby being caught in pillows or falling out of bed. Detective Inspector Phil Jackson, of West Yorkshire Police, told the court how he had spoken at length with the infant's parents following her death. He said: It's obvious they were both caring and loving parents. As part of the process I went to the scene and reviewed what was there but there were no signs of neglect.

title: jilted groom 40 whose younger
story: NewsJilted groom, 40, whose younger bride ran off DAYS after £30k wedding hit out at "doubters" ahead of ceremonyAndy Mitchell, 40, was shocked to be dumped by his new wife Meaghan just 16 days after their lavish wedding in Mexico&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCharlotte Neal18:42, 21 JUN 2018Updated18:47, 21 JUN 2018NewsAndy had blasted doubters in the weeks running up to the ceremony (Image: Facebook / Deadline News)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A heartbroken groom whose new wife ran off with another man just 16 days after their wedding had hit out at doubters before their lavish &pound30,000 ceremony.  Andy Mitchell, 40, and Meaghan, 21, tied the knot in Mexico - but less than week later he was stunned to discover she was having an affair. Just hours after they declared 'til death do us part on June 3, the groom posted on Facebook seeming to hit out at those questioning whether they had really be together forever. For all those doubters, get it up yi, he said, while describing his wife as the most unbelievable looking woman I have ever seen in my, she looked sensational. The gushing newlywed added: No words can describe how beautiful she was, a wedding only most can dream about and we made it reality.  And on Valentine's Day he had also hinted that their relationship was not without its struggles, when he posted on Facebook: Against all the odds and all the doubters which tbf was probably every single person we know were only weeks away from becoming husband and wife. Starting to sink in a bit now, love you Meaghan, the only person I know that can draw every emotion out of me in 1 day ha, life will never be dull with you around and I wouldn’t change you for the world. Life is good. Happy Valentine's Day. Ps, still think ur punching a tad bud. But taxi service manager Andy quickly came crashing down from cloud nine soon after the wedding when he discovered his wife was being unfaithful.  He put his ring up for sale for &pound400 and posted messages shared between Meaghan and her lover. Andy, from Kelty, Fife, claimed the affair started on her hen night. The bride admitted the affair but claimed she had not slept with her lover until after the wedding. Meaghan said: We did not have sex on our hen do - it was after the wedding. I didn't do anything on my hen night.  We know what we've done and take full responsibility. I was young and naive when I first got with him. Andy and Meaghan married in Akumal Bay Beach Resort, Mexico, at a lavish wedding attended by friends and family, on which they personally spent &pound6,000. Photos of the wedding on Facebook show the apparently happy couple frolicking on the beach with their well-dressed guests. But barely a fortnight later the groom decided to make a very public statement that their marriage was over. He posted on Facebay Fife, advertising the rings: Hi, recently I got married in Mexico on the 3rd of June and this was the wedding set I used while Meaghan Mitchell said her marriage vows. He claimed: However, six days later I found out she started having an affair on her hen night and it carried on for eight weeks through our dream wedding. The previous day he posted a series of what he claims were screenshots of his wife's phone that appeared to show an intimate conversation between two people.

title: passengers stranded bournemouth airport after
story: NewsPassengers stranded at Bournemouth Airport after 300 car keys dumped in holdall when parking firm went bustA free-for-all broke out as travellers landing at the airport tried to find their keys in the bag when BOMO Parking Services ceased trading unexpectedly&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByCorey Ross10:34, 21 JUN 2018Updated10:38, 21 JUN 2018NewsLisa Russell and friends Charlotte and Aiden Thorn were left stranded at the airport for hours (Image: BournemouthDailyEcho/BNPS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHundreds of passengers' car keys were dumped in a holdall at an airport after a parking firm went bust without warning.  An employee from BOMO Parking Services turned up at Bournemouth Airport in Dorset and left the bag containing about 300 customers keys at an information desk.  He then reportedly fled the airport without saying a word to anyone. Staff had the challenge of matching up the keys to holidaymakers arriving home from breaks in Europe. There were chaotic scenes in the terminal building as passengers tried to find their keys and cars that had been parked off-site. Airport security staff had to drive people half a mile to the car park to collect their vehicles.  One group of four friends from Southampton - Lisa and Michael Russell and Charlotte and Aidan Thorne - were left stranded at the airport after their keys were lost in the chaos. They had to call out a locksmith to get into their vehicle. Many customers were unaware there was any problem until they arrived back from their holidays, although some reported receiving a text or email from the company stating it had gone bust. In a statement, BOMO Parking Service blamed the decision to fold the company on a sustained attack on its business by a known individual which had a catastrophic effect. Three weeks ago two customers' cars were defaced in a vandalism attack and valeting equipment and CCTV cameras were also damaged.  Holidaymaker Mrs Russell, who had been on holiday in Malaga, said they had no idea the parking company was in trouble. She said: We used them once before and had absolutely no problem and even when we were leaving they were very friendly - there was no worry about anything going wrong. We had no message from the company explaining what's happened. But to come back and find that your keys have been lost and you can't get home is really upsetting. The airport staff have been really helpful and it's not their fault this has happened. It's just such a shame that we've had a wonderful holiday and then this happens as soon as we come back.  In a statement on its website BOMO Parking Services said: BOMO Parking Services has ceased trading with immediate effect. All vehicle keys have been hand delivered to Bournemouth Airport information desk for customers to collect on their return from holiday. All future car park bookings have been cancelled with immediate effect. BOMO Parking Services has been the target of a sustained attack online and offline by a known individual, which has had a catastrophic effect on the trading position, causing closure. An airport employee said staff from the company had been at the airport on Tuesday and had not given any suggestion that anything was wrong, even discussing the fact they had installed new top-of-the-range CCTV cameras to replace the ones that had been destroyed. The company's site was based at land next to the Adventure Wonderland theme park, close to the airport.

title: student developed anorexia after starving
story: NewsStudent developed anorexia after starving herself to fit into bridesmaid's dress for sister's weddingKatie Smith, 18, from Manchester, plummeted to a shocking 6st 7lbs in weight after she began starving herself, using 40 laxatives a day and jogging on the spot for hours&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola Moors19:21, 21 JUN 2018NewsKatie Smith, 18, developed anorexia after hating the way she looked when trying on dresses for her sister's wedding (Image: HotSpot Media)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn anorexia survivor developed an eating disorder after starving herself to fit into a bridesmaid's dress for her sister's wedding. Katie Smith, 18, from Oldham, Manchester, dropped to just 6st 7lbs after losing a shocking 4st 7lbs, and was so skinny that she wore children's size 10-11 clothes. Then aged 15, Katie restricted her food to just 100 calories a day, consumed 40 laxatives and jogged on the spot for hours. But, in November 2017, after being admitted for inpatient treatment, she recovered and now weighs 10st 2lbs and is a size 10.  Katie, a student at North Chadderton Sixth Form College, says: I realised that if I carried on, I would die. It really made me want to get better. Having an eating disorder was awful, I never thought I'd make my 18th birthday. Growing up, Katie was a competitive swimmer and was always a healthy weight. I was never bigger than a size 10 but my frame was muscly and I weighed around 11st, she said. It was never anything that I worried about though.  But in February 2014, then aged 14, Katie developed bulimia. I would binge eat up to 5,000 calories before purging it up, she said. It became a cycle but, all the extra calories made me gain weight. In December 2015, Katie was trying on a size 12 bridesmaid's dress for the wedding of her sister, Joanne, 34, a teacher, when her eating patterns spiralled out of control. Katie said she felt horrendous.  The fabric clung to my figure and I hated how I looked, she said. After that, I developed anorexia. I exercised excessively every day, jogging on the spot for hours and performing 500 sit-ups. I only allowed myself to eat 100 calories of vegetables daily and I took 40 laxatives. Some days I'd eat nothing and I weighed myself constantly. I was determined to fit into the dress and look skinny at the wedding. I wanted to look good for the pictures.  Unsurprisingly, Katie's weight plummeted and within six months, her 5ft 5in frame weighed just 6st 7lbs. She added: I could fit into size 10-11 children's clothes, but I purposefully wore baggy clothes to hide how bony my frame was. I even stopped swimming when I was 14 so mum would never realise how skinny I'd gotten. My muscles ached constantly and I always felt cold. I had to wear multiple layers of clothes and my periods completely stopped. Handfuls of hair would fall out while I was in the shower and I'd be left with clumps of hair on my pillow. It was terrifying. In February 2016, Katie attended her sister's wedding in Ireland and by this point she'd already lost 2st 7lbs leaving her a size 6 and 8st 7lbs.  I was really looking forward to the wedding but on the day, I felt awful, she said. I didn't manage any of the wedding food. I felt huge even though now I realise I wasn't. My dress was a size 8 and hung off me. I pretended to family members that I'd eaten and played with the food on my plate. In March 2016 Katie was diagnosed with anorexia by her psychiatrist and she was admitted as an inpatient at the Hope Unit, Bury, Greater Manchester, where she underwent therapy for three months. A month later, she reached her lowest weight of 6st 7lbs. In June 2016, she was discharged as an outpatient but she relapsed over the summer.  Katie said: I felt self-conscious about my weight and how I looked, especially when my friends were wearing bikinis. I started restricting food again. It got completely out of control. For the next 17 months until November 2017, Katie was in and out of hospital battling her eating disorder. It was tough I missed a year of college to concentrate on getting better, she said. Then one day, I realised that I didn't want to die I knew that if I carried on, I wouldn't make it. I upped my calorie intake and stopped exercising. I realised my health was more important.

title: toddler severe psoriasis called lobster
story: NewsToddler with severe psoriasis called 'lobster' and shunned by strangers who ask if she is contagiousMaisie Buchanan, of Falkirk, Scotland, has a skin condition which causes her body to go bright red and scaly&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly16:43, 21 JUN 2018Updated16:53, 21 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe furious mum of a toddler with a severe condition which causes her skin to become lobster red have hit out at the hurtful strangers who make cruel jibes and accuse her of neglect. Maisie Buchanan, two, was diagnosed with infant psoriasis as a baby and spent weeks in hospital . The rare condition causes her skin to flare-up and turn bright red and scaly. But her disgusted parents Lesley Buchanan, 35, and Alistair Buchanan, 36, have become fed-up at cruel strangers shunning her in the street and even accusing them of scalding their child.  Lesley said: People assume the worst and that she's been scalded. Others have asked if I left her out in the sun too long or forgot to put her sun hat on. They will ask me 'what's wrong with her?' like I'm a neglectful parent. I always respond 'there's nothing wrong with her, she's a happy sweet little girl with a skin condition.' Maisie's skin is very flushed, it can go lobster red, and if she's flaking she looks different. People pick up on that and it's very hurtful. It really hurts that people think like that, it's like a knife to the heart.  Lesley and Alistair, from Falkirk, Scotland, have to slather their daughter in skin cream four times a day to help treat psoriasis, which has eased since her diagnosis in early 2017. The tot also has to have weekly injections of medicine. She wears special mittens to stop her clawing at her skin during the night. But Lesley continued: My husband was with her in a supermarket when her face was very inflamed and a woman in her sixties said to him 'look at the state of your child'. She implied that he couldn't look after his child if her face looks like that.  I just want to get a megaphone and shout 'it's infant psoriasis and she's not contagious'. I feel like saying 'she's not going to lick you and you're not going to catch something'. It's when adults say something that it's upsetting. I've heard children say 'what's wrong with that baby's skin?' but that doesn't bother me as they are curious about it. With adults common sense seems to go out the window. I've had people look at her and ask if she's contagious and move their children away with a look of passive disgust on her face.  Recalling the traumatic diagnosis, retail supervisor Lesley said: We spoke to the health visitor who thought she might have been teething and rubbing her face but the mark got bigger and another appeared on her right cheek.

title: uk weather brits to see
story: NewsUK weather: Brits 'to see hottest June in 42 years' with 30C heatwave despite SNOW on summer solsticeFootball fans are set to enjoy a "BBQ weekend" with 27C highs as England take on Panama in the World Cup - and the weather will only get warmer&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySophie EvansBrett GibbonsAlistair Grant13:45, 21 JUN 2018Updated15:57, 21 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrits are set to sizzle in temperatures above 30C as a heatwave sweeps the country - with June on course to be the hottest for 42 years.  Some parts of the UK are expected to see up to 10 days of sweltering temperatures, despite freak snow on the summer solstice.  Football fans will likely enjoy a BBQ weekend with 27C highs - with England due to take on Panama in the World Cup on Sunday. And by the middle of next week, temperatures could hit the low 30s.  The warm weather will roast large parts of Britain, with high pressure dragging baking air from the Mediterranean across the country.     Some computer models have indicated there will be a prolonged hot spell for areas of southern England, the Midlands and Wales. For locations further north , the values are only slightly lower. June is on track to be Britain’s hottest for 42 years, since 1976’s famous heatwave, Met Office statistics for the first half of June show. The UK average temperature of 14.7C - 1.7C above normal - from June 1-14 is the warmest June since 1976’s 15.0C over the whole of the month, figures show. June’s rainfall is also down by half – at just 19mm – amid 82 hours of sunshine, the Met Office said.  Met Office forecaster Bonnie Diamond said: “It’s warming up from the weekend and for next week as high pressure drags up warmer air from the continent. “Sunday could see 26C and from Wednesday looks like the low 30s in the South, with sunny and warm weather lasting until at least the end of next week.” Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “It’s a BBQ weekend, with 27C possible by Sunday. In contrast, snow and -12C windchill surprised summer solstice hikers on the longest day of the year as a one-day chill hit from Iceland. And there is more snow forecast later on Scotland’s higher ground following flurries near Glen Affric, near Loch Ness, Highland.  Taking to Twitter today, professional photographer James Roddie wrote: “Snowing on the summits!” Mountain Weather Information Service said: “Showers snow are possible on the highest tops, with wind chill feeling like -10C or locally colder.” Despite this, experts are confident that the UK will bask in very warm temperatures by the beginning of next week.  A scorching southerly air flow is expected to blow northwards from France​, Spain and Portugal​, The Weather Channel says.  ​The mercury could rocket into the low 30s by Wednesday under baking sunshine, with just a light breeze.  ​​Meteorologist Amy Hodgson, of The Weather Channel, said: “It is looking like we’re going to get some lovely hot and sunny weather. “There is now high confidence that temperatures will increase to above to well-above normal through next week. “Sunny, dry and very warm conditions are expected across much of Europe under high pressure that will be centred across the British Isles on Monday, with temperatures reaching the high 20s across England. “As the high gradually drifts eastwards through the midweek period, temperatures will rise further in the southerly flow around the western flank of the high.

story: AdvertorialWhere to spend Summer Solstice: UK location that will have the latest sunset on the longest day of the yearSummer is officially here which means more daylight hours for fun with the family&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDave Masters14:05, 21 JUN 2018Updated16:02, 21 JUN 2018AdvertorialThe sun rises behind clouds over Stonehenge, which has been a place of worship and celebration at the time of Summer Solstice for thousands of years (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThursday 21 June is the summer solstice, which marks the official start of summer as well as the Northern Hemisphere's longest day.  And that means there are more daylight hours to have some fun with your family! So why not make the most of the extra daylight by getting out and about for some fun activities? Although the time of sunset varies between the south of the UK and the north, you should expect between 16.5 and 17.5 hours of daylight. So why not plan a late picnic or watch the sun set over the coast? The longest longest day  Want to maximise the amount of daylight you get? Head north. The further you go, the more daylight hours you’ll have. At the North Pole, summer months are constantly lit by a never setting sun. But going to the North Pole is tricky enough at the best of times, let alone on a Thursday afternoon when you have work the next day.  But there are less extreme trips you can make. For example, even the northern tip of Scotland sees days that are longer than those in at the tip of Cornwall. Indeed, on the summer solstice it's common for a kind of all-night twilight that means it never really feels like night. If you want to experience the longest day in the UK then you should jump on a plane to Orkney. The island of Unst has the most northerly campsite in the UK called Saxa Vord Resort. It's here that you can experience a day that lasts 19 hours and 10 minutes, with a sunset at 10:40pm. That's great for a late picnic or barbecue - but less than ideal if you're trying to get some sleep! If you're going to make this journey, don't forget to get the Garmin Drive Sat Nav , above, for the bit you're doing in a car. With lifetime map updates you're never going to find yourself driving down a newly-closed street or down a disused road. Scilly isn't the most accessible place in the UK and you'll need to catch a propeller-powered plane to the island from Cornwall and from there a boat to St Agnes. The island of St Agnes has a campsite called Troytown, which will see only 16 hours, 21 minutes and 24 seconds of daylight. Sunset is still at 9:37 though, which is pretty late if you've got very little ones. The views from the campsite are spectacular though, with views out over the sea and lush green grass all around. story: NewsWoman moves 4,000 miles from America to Leeds for man she met on dog lovers' Facebook groupSamm Sexton, 29, is moving from Indiana, USA, to Leeds, West Yorkshire, to live with Alex Musk after the pair bonded over their love of animals&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly19:29, 21 JUN 2018NewsAlex Musk and Samm Sexton got engaged two days after meeting (Image: Mercury Press &amp Media)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA call centre worker is about to move more than 4,000 miles to the UK to marry a man she met on a Facebook dog lovers' group. Alex Musk, 30, proposed to Samm Sexton, 29, just two days after meeting her earlier this month. Samm had spent &pound1,138 on flights from Indiana, USA, to the UK for a two-week trip to meet Alex after chatting on a Facebook community. The pair bonded for six months online after discovering they both had beloved Boston terriers named Lola.  And just days into the trip, Alex dropped down on one knee and popped the question during a romantic picnic in Leeds, West Yorks. I was beyond excited when Alex asked me to marry him - it just felt so right. During the time we were apart we'd talk all day every day. In his lunch break he'd call me and we were in constant contact, Samm said. The call centre worker flew back to the US on Thursday but is hoping to get a visa to stay in the UK permanently.  She added: I saw him then he looked up and saw me and I couldn't stop smiling. He was everything I'd hoped he'd be. It was amazing to get my arms around him finally. When he proposed I wasn't too surprised. I knew it was coming but I thought it was amazing. As for moving from the US to the UK, I'm excited for it. It will be a huge difference but it's one I'm ready for. My family and friends are very supportive. They will miss me of course but we will still visit and keep in touch.  The couple are now planning their wedding in which their beloved dogs, Alex's two-year-old and Samm's seven-year-old Boston terriers, will play starring roles. Alex, who is a disability support worker, said: Last Saturday we visited York overnight and I proposed to her then. I knew by January that I wanted to marry her but waited until we were together to pop the question. We went for a picnic at York Museum Gardens and I asked her then. It was an immediate yes. I bought the ring two months ago, it's a moonstone ring that Samm said she loved so I ordered it in secret. Her eyes lit up when I got down on one knee and her hands flew to her face.

title: fed up woman teaches rude
story: NewsFed up woman teaches rude house guest a lesson - but her husband thinks she's in the wrongIt all came to a head over dinner - and now the wife is in the dog house&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor13:17, 21 JUN 2018NewsWe ALL know a Gary (Image: The Image Bank)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe all know someone who loves to talk. Maybe that person is even you. There's a fine line, however, between being a chatterbox and alienating everyone around because of your incessant droning on and love-affair with the sound of your own voice. Conversation is a two-way street. You have to listen as well as be heard.  Sadly, not everyone has got this memo. Like Gary, for example, who came to stay with Reddit user Bri, and spent the duration of his visit talking about himself, talking over others, and not listening.  So Bri got her own back - and is now in dog house. My husband Will has a friend named Gary who arrived on Sunday night to stay with us for the week, she begins.  Gary and Will are friends from university and while they used be close, they've not seen each other in years. Bri continues: This is the first time I've met Gary. Three days into his visit and I'm struggling, guys. Gary talks non-stop. We're not just talking about Gary being excited at seeing his old friend, and being gossipy and chatty. Oh no. As Bri explains: He literally talked (mostly about himself) throughout the entire dinner last night. He kept talking after dinner. He kept talking until we went to bed. He has an opinion about EVERYTHING. Will and I barely got any words in or got talked over. My husband could tell I was about to lose my cool by the time I excused myself for bed. Will apologised when he came to bed and says he remembered that Gary talked a lot but did not know he was going to do it incessantly and so rudely. So the couple hatched a plan and decided we would put more effort into speaking up/interjecting.    However, the next night, Gary had somehow managed to up his game.  Tonight, the three of us went out to try a new restaurant and it didn't go well, Bri continues. Gary kept trying to monopolise the conversation and would talk over me. I said 'EXCUSE ME, please allow me to finish', and he laughed and apologised because he 'knows he talks too much' and then KEPT TALKING. My husband then interjected and said, 'Gary I would like to hear what Bri has to say'. So Gary apologised again and let me talk. But the victory was short-lived. When I finished, he nodded and then started continuing with whatever he was saying without acknowledging my point.  Bri had had enough. In her own words: I was done being polite at this point. I was mad and highly irritated. I had already had a couple of drinks and thought, 'F**k. This. Noise.' The the food arrived - and presented Bri with the perfect opportunity for revenge. Gary just sits there in front of his plate talking and talking. So I pushed my salad aside and grabbed his plate of untouched steak. And I started eating it. He stopped talking, looked stunned, and said, 'Bri, what are you doing?' I ignored him and kept eating his steak.  He looks kind of p****d and says, 'please stop eating my steak!' I ignored him and ignored Will's death stare and kept eating Gary's steak. I ate the whole thing. They watched me and Gary didn't speak a word the whole time and I got to eat in glorious silence. Then I apologised to Gary and said some s**t like, 'I know I eat too much and should have let him finish his steak. Gary tried to like...laugh it off? He didn't talk on the ride home. Unfortunately for Bri, she can't seem to catch a break.  Now her husband is beyond p****d at me and has asked me to apologise to Gary. I've agreed to apologise because what I did was NOT the right way to handle the situation. My question is...how do I handle this for the rest of the week? Should I just stay away from him? Or is that being rude on top of my super rudeness? In this instance, no one thinks Bri is in the wrong - and it turns out A LOT of people know a Gary.
